messageBody:
> >So said Ostermueller, Erik on 2003-07-29 --------------------
> >Hello, all.
> >
> >This post isn't necessarily JUnit related,
> >but it is very unit-testing related.
> >
> >With our legacy mainframe system,
> >it is not possible to add or
> >delete data on the fly (ie, from a unit test) -- you have to rely on
> >nightly batch processes for this.
> >
> >Since the unit tests can't set up and tear down
> >their own data, we're running into lots of snags.
>
> Very annoying.
I wish more people in my shop shared your opinion.

>
> >Have you all encountered similar situations?
> >How have you worked with or worked around them?
>
> Do your tests need to do the mainframe update? Is that what
> you're actually testing?
Optimally, yes, they need to do the update.
We want to test our own code (thin client) and
the integration of our code with the host.

>
> Is it enough to verify that you submit the request correctly?
> Use the Golden Master technique
is this a specific pattern (perhaps documented somewhere)?
> -- handcraft a working
> request for a batch update, then verify that your code
> generates an equivalent request. Either use text or some kind
> of object to represent the request.
This might be a good "Plan B".
Thanks
